question_text: Homonymous hemianopia:

options.option_a: (ACA) is incorrect because the anterior cerebral artery supplies medial frontal and parietal lobes and is not involved in the primary visual pathway. Option b (MCA) is also incorrect because, although the MCA supplies lateral cortex including sensorimotor areas, it generally spares the deep visual pathway structures. Option c (Anterior choroidal artery) is correct as it directly supplies the optic tract and lateral geniculate nucleus, causing homonymous hemianopia when infarcted.

question_text: 56-year-old male with Hx of memory loss for 24 hours & asking the same question repeatedly, investigation

options.option_a: (CT & CTA) is correct because it meets the urgency of diagnosing acute cerebrovascular events and provides both hemorrhage exclusion and vascular assessment. Option b (MRI) while sensitive for ischemia, is less appropriate in the emergency setting due to longer scan times and possible contraindications. The marked answer (B) is therefore incorrect.

question_text: Case about patient with recurrent epistaxis & Telangiectasia over- skin. - mucous membranes - retina & GIT. What to do next:

options.option_a: (Annual MRI brain) is not routinely indicated unless neurological symptoms develop. Option b (Regular BP check
options.option_c: (ECHO) may help screen for pulmonary arteriovenous malformations but does not tackle the GI bleeding risk. Option d (Endoscopy) is the correct next step as it directly evaluates and may treat gastrointestinal telangiectasias responsible for chronic bleeding.
